replies.body:
Ggwp, Turkey

Turkish Armed Forces have completely taken over the administration of the country to reinstate constitutional order, human rights and freedoms, the rule of law and general security that was damaged.

“All international agreements are still valid. We hope that all of our good relationships with all countries will continue.”

http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/07/15/turkey-low-flying-jets-and-gunfire-heard-in-ankara1/

replies.body:
In my personal opinion this is somewhat a good thing. The president doesn't seem to be a true supporter of democracy at all and with the recent terror attack the government has been shown to be weak.

However this must be a terrifying night for the Turkish people, thoughts go out to everyone in the country.

replies.body:
Actually, that's a good thing.

The last Military coup in Turkey was in the 1980s. And military coups of Turkey were initiated to repel fundamentalist ideals inside the government and bring about more secularism.

Erdogan... that man is a monster. What he does to journalists and commits censorship. The man needs to be arrested or executed.

Also, to note when the military succeeds in these coups they actually make sure that a new president is instated - democratically. One who will protect the peoples' rights.

A lot of the time, being the opposite of democratic is a good thing.

Also, to note when the military succeeds in these coups they actually make sure that a new president is instated - democratically. One who will protect the peoples' rights.

A lot of the time, being the opposite of democratic is a good thing.

replies.body:
However, this coup is different. Whenever there is a military coup the military is unified... however they're currently split.

So... three outcomes.

Coup fails and Erdogan uses this as an opportunity to institute laws similar to Saudi Arabia (A VERY bad time for a lot of civilians.) 

Military coup wins and a more secular president is put on power - upholding the peoples' rights.

No one wins and this persists for decades.

No one wins and this persists for decades.

replies.body:
It's nice to see a Turk actually opening his eyes. If you want to learn more about how much people your country has killed (my people), search the Armenian Genocide up. It's a mass killing which your people commuted 101 years ago that president Erdogan refuses to accept. 1.5 million people were killed in total.

I wouldnt be be saying this if you didn't say what you said. If you don't believe that your people did this 100 years ago, it's fine, I don't want to start a flame war. If you have any more questions about this topic PM me on Skype and I'll answer when I get back from vacation. 

Also, you know the world is fucked up when you leave home for 8 days and come back knowing there was a terrorist attack in Nice and a military coop in Turkey within those 8 days.

replies.body: You know they didn't just send us out of Turkey right? They literally made my ancestors walk across a lot of miles (idk if it's more than 100 or a thousand, I don't want to give false information, but I do know they made us cross the Der Zor desert). Fortunately, Turkey tried to advance on the second part of Armenia in 1918 we fought back and won. It was they first time we were independent in  more than 100 years.
